title: Ask HN: Help recall AI-powered personal assitant showcased recently on HN
text:
There was some thread on HN not that long ago, with a showcase of an AI personal assitant. The case study was, if I recall correct, filling in web forms and searching for apartment rentals fitting specific criteria, which is initiated by a simple text prompt without any additional tweaking.

It was not an assitant in a sense of Alexa or Mycroft, but some kind of an automation. I may be mistaken here, but it may have also come in a form of a browser extension. The showcase demo was most likely either a video or a gif.

Could anyone kindly remind me what exactly the product was and provide a link to the HN discussion?

Show HN: Proposalgenie.ai – A GPT3-Powered Upwork Proposal Generator
text:
Hi everyone!
We’re excited to announce the release of Proposal Genie, the AI-powered tool that makes it easy to create professional proposals on Upwork and start winning jobs. 
With Proposal Genie, you’ll be able to create proposals from any device, build a reusable profile with all your information, and add additional optional fields like keywords, length, and tone to give your proposals that extra touch. Plus, we have some several upcoming features that will make proposal writing a breeze.
You can now sign up for the beta version of Proposal Genie for free at www.proposalgenie.ai and start creating winning proposals today. 
With Proposal Genie, you’ll be able to streamline your proposal process and increase your chances of getting hired on Upwork, so you can start making money faster.
If you have any questions or feedback, please don’t hesitate to reach out. We’re always looking to improve and make Proposal Genie the best it can be.

Ask HN: Why are intro to CS courses almost always intro to programming?
text:
We all are aware that Computer Science is not programming and programming is not CS. Then why do almost all introduction to CS courses teach programming in the fancy popular language of the time?

Shouldn't introduction to CS be all about learning principles of the discipline in a broad perspective which then branch out to several specialised subjects later on?

And shouldn't introduction to programming be a separate course that teaches the way to program to achieve some concrete goals like building something?

Example: Wood carving techniques are taught to learn how to carve a piece of wood to build a small sculpture or something. Not to teach the principles of wood carving to become a master wood carving artist. Those things are separate.
